titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the John F. Saddington property records 1977.046
titlestmt.author: Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-09-20 19:31:46 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: This collection contains legal documents dating from 1886 and pertaining to the property located at 491 Putnam Avenue in Brooklyn, N.Y., conveyed by John F. Saddington to Rhoda Walmsley.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: John F. Saddington was a resident of Brooklyn, N.Y., who at one point owned property at 491 Putnam Avenue. He was married to Minnie P. Saddington.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); John F. Saddington property records, 1977.046, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Minimally processed to the collection level.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains legal documents dating from 1886 and pertaining to the property located at 491 Putnam Avenue in Brooklyn, N.Y., conveyed by John F. Saddington to Rhoda Walmsley. Items include an agreement, deed, mortgage and bond, and title abstract featuring a record of ownership of the property since 1781 and a plot of the block and lot where the property is located.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: These materials are in the public domain.

While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
